title: NEDOCS Score for Emergency Department Overcrowding
description: Estimates severity of overcrowding in emergency departments using 7 objective parameters including ED and hospital bed capacity, patient volume, ventilator usage, admission counts, and wait times.

parameters.name: ed_beds
parameters.description: Number of ED beds (total licensed number of beds)

parameters.name: total_patients
parameters.description: Total patients in the ED (include patients doubled up in rooms and hallway beds)

parameters.name: ventilated_patients
parameters.description: Patients on ventilators in the ED

parameters.name: admitted_patients
parameters.description: Number of admits in the ED

parameters.name: longest_admit_wait
parameters.description: Waiting time of longest admitted patient

parameters.name: longest_waiting_room_wait
parameters.description: Waiting time of longest waiting room patient (technically 'Last roomed patient's prior wait time')

ranges.interpretation: The emergency department is operating smoothly with minimal patient load and adequate resources.
The emergency department is experiencing moderate patient volume but remains functional with acceptable wait times.
The emergency department is very busy with high patient volume, but resources are still adequate to manage patient flow effectively.
The emergency department is overcrowded with inadequate resources for patient volume. Patient care may be compromised and wait times are excessive.
The emergency department is severely overcrowded with critical resource limitations. Patient safety is at risk and immediate measures should be taken.
The emergency department is dangerously overcrowded. Patient safety is severely compromised and emergency measures must be implemented immediately.

references: Weiss SJ, et al. Estimating the Degree of Emergency Department Overcrowding in Academic Medical Centers: Results of the National ED Overcrowding Study (NEDOCS). Acad Emerg Med. 2004 Jan;11(1):38-50.
Hwang U, et. al. Measures of Crowding in the Emergency Department: A Systematic Review. Acad Emerg Med. 2011; 18:527–538
Hoot N, Aronsky D. An Early Warning System for Overcrowding in the Emergency Department. AMIA Annual Symposium Proceedings 2006;2006:339-343.
formula: NEDOCS = -20 + 85.8 × (Total ED patients / ED beds) + 600 × (ED admits / Hospital beds) + 13.3 × (Ventilated patients) + 0.93 × (Longest admit time in hours) + 5.64 × (Last patient wait time in hours)
notes: NEDOCS was validated in academic medical centers and may need adjustment for community hospitals
The score ranges from 1 to 200, with higher scores indicating greater overcrowding
Consider local factors and clinical judgment when interpreting results
Regular monitoring can help predict and prevent dangerous overcrowding situations
